instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in retrieving the maize leaf area index in low-input crop systems in southern Mozambique?
Output: In retrieving the maize leaf area index in low-input crop systems in southern Mozambique,the researchers used remote sensing spectrum.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in retrieving the maize leaf area index in low-input crop systems in southern Mozambique?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used in retrieving the maize leaf area index in low-input crop systems in southern Mozambique were hyperspectral and multispectral data.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the accuracy in retrieving the maize leaf area index in low-input crop systems in southern Mozambique?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the retrieval in the related study was the root mean square error (RMSE). The RMSE measures the average difference between the predicted and actual values of the maize leaf area index. 

As for how far this metric can go, it provides a quantitative measure of the accuracy of the retrieval method. A lower RMSE value indicates a higher level of accuracy, while a higher RMSE value indicates a lower level of accuracy.

instruction: What machine learning regression algorithms were selected for the hyperspectral and multispectral datasets, and for the Sentinel-2 dataset, in order to retrieve the maize leaf area index in low-input crop systems in southern Mozambique?
Output: For the hyperspectral and multispectral datasets, the relevant vector machine (RVM) was selected as the machine learning regression algorithm. For the Sentinel-2 dataset, the support vector machine (SVM) was selected as the machine learning regression algorithm.

instruction: How does the accuracy of the vegetation indices compare to the other two approaches in retrieving the maize leaf area index in low-input crop systems in southern Mozambique?
Output: The accuracy of the vegetation indices was found to be higher compared to the other two approaches (statistical approach and look-up-table inversion approach) in retrieving the maize leaf area index in low-input crop systems in southern Mozambique. Among the vegetation indices tested, the three band spectral index (TBSIb: 665; 865; 783) was identified as the most accurate index, with a root mean square error (RMSE) of 0.35. This suggests that using vegetation indices derived from field spectra and Sentinel-2 images can provide more accurate estimates of the maize leaf area index in the study area.
